text: chris hadfield not content with being
the first Canadian to walk in space now
you've recorded an album up there what
gave you the inspiration you know it
wasn't really any master plan there's a
guitar that is permanently up on the
space station and I imagine they're
playing it every night up there right
now and and when I had a little quiet
time just before sleep I play that
guitar and and you just sort of
naturally try and capture what you and
you write songs and you play songs that
you know and I just thought just like
taking photographs to try and capture
the experience I started recording those
songs while I was up there and and after
the mission was over ahead about 15 or
16 songs total and they've been sitting
for a couple years doing nothing and I
thought it would just make sense to put
them all together in an album and get
them out were where other people can
hear them also
float away
but you to ride a lot ha ha
ready to play just how difficult was it
though to record up there in space it's
harder than you might think for a couple
different reasons one is there's no
proper place to record I ended up
choosing my little sleep pod which is
which is not much bigger than I like
like maybe it's the size of a coffin you
know and so you're trying to squeeze a
guitar in there to play and then there's
physiological changes your head never
drains and clear so you always have the
feeling of a head cold and the guitar
kind of has to get held hard into place
so what that's sort of part of it laura
is the changes are what helps define how
the music sounds and and I'm really
delighted how the music came out is for
me it's immensely evocative of where
I've been and the experience of living
on board a spaceship your version of
space oddity records that there became a
youtube sensation with this latest album
are you hoping to make space more
accessible to us earthlings well I guess
sort of indirectly it's it's the same
idea for me as talking to school kids
about it and while I'm talking to them I
show them images of it because often an
image becomes more compelling than just
words and music can be so much more
compelling than just words also and it's
not like we're just starting to probe
space anymore we've been living as 15
different nations onboard the space
station for the last 15 years and how do
you express the humanity of that be the
personal experience of that to people
and music I think as you mentioned as
seen in space oddity I think people got
a little insight into what it's actually
like to be living on board the space
station a little more clearly like you
can't express it really any other way
like you can through music so hopefully
people will maybe get a little more
fundamental emotional and human
understanding of what it's like to be
off to planet Chris Hadfield thank you
very much for joining us Thank You
Laurie nice to talk with you
